Remind Your Way:
Clean The Noise,
Highlight The Value

The Value

Principles

Tips

Stop thinking about decorations, start thinking about the value.

The only thing that matters is the data your audience is came for. Design, layouts, make-up and decorations are just your tools to highlight the value.

Imagine you have 30 secs to pitch your data. What would you say? What decision maker need to know? How would you present it? What would you highlight? What would you hide?

That's it. That's the only thing that matters. Delete the noise. Make your audience satisfied.

Search

js/search.js

v.1.1 Stable | Download file_download

IfÂ you need search onÂ aÂ static website, the easiest and most reliable option isÂ toÂ use aÂ ready-made library instead ofÂ building your own search from scratch. ItÂ works out ofÂ the box, isÂ free toÂ use, and has already been tested onÂ many real websites. One such library â€” and the one used onÂ this site â€” isÂ Pagefind.

Pagefind isÂ aÂ fast and privacy-friendly search engine designed specifically for static sites. ItÂ scans the already-built HTML pages and creates aÂ small client-side index, soÂ search works instantly inÂ the browser without any backend orÂ third-party service. OnÂ Eleventy sites, Pagefind integrates right after the build step and indexes only what isÂ actually deployed toÂ production.

Installation

  1. Run the installation command from the root directory of your project. This will add Pagefind to your development dependencies.
npm i -D pagefind
  1. Update the build and start scripts. Open your package.json file and modify the â€œscriptsâ€ section soÂ that Pagefind runs automatically after Eleventy builds the site, and soÂ that both can beÂ run together during local development.
"scripts": {
    "start": "eleventy --serve & pagefind --source _site",
    "build": "eleventy",
    "postbuild": "pagefind --source _site"
},
  1. Verify that the dependencies are listed inÂ package.json. InÂ the same file, scroll down toÂ the â€œdevDependenciesâ€ section and make sure that both @11ty/eleventy and pagefind are present with valid version numbers.
"devDependencies": {
    "@11ty/eleventy": "^3.1.0",
    "pagefind": "^1.1.0"
}

IfÂ the installation was successful, they should appear there automatically.

Adding the Search UI to the Website

First, weÂ need anÂ element that will allow users toÂ open the search interface. InÂ this example, weÂ place aÂ button search inÂ the website header next toÂ the hamburger menu:

<div class="header-icons">
  <button class="icon-search no-decoration" id="search-button" aria-label="ĞŸĞ¾Ğ¸ÑĞº">
      <span class="material-icons">search</span>
  </button>
  <button class="hamburger no-decoration" aria-label="Toggle navigation">
      <span class="material-icons icon-menu">menu</span>
      <span class="material-icons icon-close">close</span>
  </button>
</div>

Next, create aÂ container that will hold both the search input and the search results. Initially itÂ isÂ hidden until the user clicks the search button.

<div class="search-wrapper">
  <div id="searchbar" class="searchbar" hidden>
    <div id="search" class="search-input"></div>
  </div>
</div>

All necessary styles are already included inÂ Rare Styles. Pagefind also ships with its own default styles and JavaScript. Include them inside the <head> section ofÂ your layout:

<link rel="stylesheet" href="/pagefind/pagefind-ui.css">
<script src="/pagefind/pagefind-ui.js" defer></script>

Now add aÂ small JavaScript file that will initialize Pagefind UIÂ and show/hide the search panel when the user clicks the button:

function initSearchUI() {
    var btn = document.getElementById('search-button');
    var bar = document.getElementById('searchbar');
    var container = document.getElementById('search');
    var initialized = false;
    var inputListenerAdded = false;

    function openSearch() {
        if (bar) {
            bar.hidden = false;
        }
        
        if (!initialized && window.PagefindUI && container) {
            new PagefindUI({
                element: '#search',
                showSubResults: true,
                translations: { placeholder: 'Searchâ€¦' }
            });
            initialized = true;
        }
        
        setTimeout(function() {
            if (container) {
                var input = container.querySelector('input[type="text"]') || container.querySelector('input');
                if (input) {
                    if (input.focus) input.focus();
                    
                    if (!inputListenerAdded) {
                        input.addEventListener('input', function() {
                            if (!bar) return;
                            if (input.value && input.value.trim().length > 0) {
                                bar.classList.add('has-query');
                            } else {
                                bar.classList.remove('has-query');
                            }
                        });
                        inputListenerAdded = true;
                    }
                }
            }
        }, 50);
        
        document.addEventListener('keydown', escListener);
    }

    function closeSearch() {
        if (bar) {
            bar.hidden = true;
            bar.classList.remove('has-query');
        }
        document.removeEventListener('keydown', escListener);
    }

    function escListener(e) {
        if (e.key === 'Escape') closeSearch();
    }

    if (btn) {
        btn.addEventListener('click', function(e) {
            e.preventDefault();
            if (bar && bar.hidden) {
                openSearch();
            } else {
                closeSearch();
            }
        });
    }
}

if (document.readyState === 'loading') {
    document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', initSearchUI);
} else {
    initSearchUI();
}

Finally, make sure this script isÂ included atÂ the end ofÂ the page, before </body>:

<script src="/assets/js/search.js"></script>

After you start the site locally and Pagefind finishes indexing (for example byÂ running npm run start from your terminal), the search UIÂ should beÂ fully functional.

You can always customize how the search results look byÂ applying your own styles.

Indexing Controls

Pagefind gives you several simple HTML-based controls toÂ fine-tune what gets indexed and how search results are ranked. These settings are added directly inÂ your templates using attributes orÂ meta tags. The full list ofÂ options isÂ available inÂ the official documentation, below are the ones you will most likely need inÂ practice.

Excluding aÂ page from the index

IfÂ aÂ page should never appear inÂ search results (for example, the search page itself orÂ some drafts), set aÂ flag inÂ the template:

{% set pagefind_exclude = true %}

Then inÂ your layout <head> section, add aÂ conditional meta tag:

{% if pagefind_exclude %}
  <meta name="pagefind:exclude" content="true">
{% endif %}

Any page with this flag will be completely removed from the index.

Limiting the indexed area on a page

ByÂ default, Pagefind indexes the entire visible HTML. ToÂ prevent navigation bars, footers, hidden UIÂ elements orÂ banners from being indexed, you can explicitly mark only the â€œcontentâ€ area using data-pagefind-body:

<header> â€¦ navigation, logo â€¦ </header>

<main data-pagefind-body>
    <!-- only this content will be indexe -->
    <h1>Article title</h1>
    <p>Some text of the articleâ€¦</p>
</main>

<footer> â€¦ contacts, copyright â€¦ </footer>

Everything outside the data-pagefind-body container will beÂ ignored during indexing.

Ignoring specific elements

When you doÂ not want toÂ restructure the layout orÂ you only need toÂ ignore aÂ few blocks, you can mark them individually:

<nav data-pagefind-ignore>â€¦</nav>
<div class="sidebar" data-pagefind-ignore>â€¦</div>
<div class="ads" data-pagefind-ignore>â€¦</div>

Ignored nodes and everything inside them will not beÂ indexed.

Prioritizing certain pages inÂ search results

You can give some pages more â€œweightâ€ soÂ they will appear higher inÂ search results. For example, toÂ boost blog posts over static pages:

<html data-pagefind-weight="10">

And for lower-priority pages:

<html data-pagefind-weight="2">

Higher values result in higher ranking when relevance is equal.

Additional configuration

Pagefind also supports optional configuration for translations, filters, metadata-based filtering, and other advanced options (for example: restricting results byÂ tags, grouping byÂ content type, orÂ customizing UIÂ strings). These features are configured either through HTML attributes orÂ through the PagefindUI initialization options. Refer toÂ the official documentation for the full list ofÂ supported options.

Search Page

InÂ addition toÂ the â€œoverlayâ€ search opened from aÂ button inÂ the header, you may also want toÂ have aÂ stand-alone search page atÂ /search/. This isÂ useful when you want aÂ full-page search experience (especially onÂ mobile), orÂ when users expect search toÂ exist asÂ aÂ real page inÂ navigation.

1. Create aÂ new template for the search page.

Create aÂ file such asÂ search.njk with the following front matter and markup:

---
layout: page
title: Search
permalink: /search/
pagefind_exclude: true # doÂ not index this page itself
disable_header_search: true # hide the overlay-search button onÂ this page
body_class: page-search # optional CSS hook
---

<div id="search-page"></div>

<script>
  document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function () {
    if (window.PagefindUI) {
      new PagefindUI({
        element: '#search-page',   // stand-alone search container
        showSubResults: true,
        translations: {
          placeholder: 'Searchâ€¦',
          load_more: 'Load more'
        }
      });
    }
  });
</script>

Key points:

  • pagefind_exclude: true ensures this page will not show upÂ inÂ the search results itself.
  • weÂ use aÂ different container (#search-page) soÂ itÂ does not conflict with the overlay search container.
  • weÂ optionally pass disable_header_search: true soÂ that the header button wonâ€™t show onÂ this page.

ToÂ conditionally style orÂ change behavior onÂ specific pages (for example, onÂ the dedicated search page), you can pass aÂ custom class through front matter and render itÂ onÂ the <body> element.

<body class="{{ body_class }}">

With the example above, the search page will render as:

<body class="page-search">

This makes itÂ possible toÂ target this page inÂ CSS orÂ conditionally skip overlay initialization inÂ JavaScript.

2. Hide the overlay-search button onÂ this page (optional)

InÂ your header template, wrap the search button inÂ aÂ condition:

{% ifÂ not disable_header_search %}
  <button id="search-button" ...>â€¦</button>
{% endif %}

Alternatively, you may simply hide itÂ with CSS using .page-search asÂ aÂ body class.

3. Prevent the overlay script from running onÂ the search page

IfÂ your overlay isÂ initialized byÂ aÂ global script such asÂ /assets/js/search.js, add aÂ guard atÂ the top:

// Do not initialize the overlay search on the dedicated /search/ page
if (document.body.classList.contains('page-search')) return;

This ensures there will never beÂ two search UIs active onÂ the same page.

AtÂ this point, the setup provides two independent search interfaces: anÂ overlay search that isÂ opened from the header onÂ regular pages, and aÂ dedicated /search/ page with aÂ full-page search interface. They doÂ not conflict with each other because they use separate containers and separate initialization logic. The search page itself isÂ excluded from the index soÂ itÂ never appears inÂ search results, which isÂ the recommended practice for dedicated search pages.
